conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the system and use equilibrium conditions to find the tension in each rope.
Block A is in equilibrium, so the forces acting on it must balance.
The forces acting on Block A are gravitational force and tension in rope OA.

premise: The gravitational force on Block A is \( m_A g = 5 \times 10 = 50 \, \text{N} \).
conclusion: The tension in rope OA must balance the gravitational force: \( T_{OA} = 50 \, \text{N} \).
Block B is also in equilibrium.
The forces acting on Block B are gravitational force and tension in rope OB.

premise: The gravitational force on Block B is \( m_B g = 10 \times 10 = 100 \, \text{N} \).
conclusion: The tension in rope OB must balance the gravitational force: \( T_{OB} = 100 \, \text{N} \).
At point O, the forces must also be in equilibrium.

premise: At point O, the forces must be in equilibrium.
conclusion: The forces acting at O are tension in rope OA, tension in rope OB, and tension in rope OP.

premise: Tension in rope OP is at 45Â° to the vertical.
conclusion: Resolve the tension in rope OP into its vertical and horizontal components: Vertical component: \( T_{OP} \sin 45^\circ \), Horizontal component: \( T_{OP} \cos 45^\circ \).

premise: Both conditions give the same result for \( T_{OP} \): \( T_{OP} = 100 \sqrt{2} \approx 141.4 \, \text{N} \).
conclusion: Final Answer: Tension in rope OA: \( 50 \, \text{N} \), Tension in rope OB: \( 100 \, \text{N} \), Tension in rope OP: \( 100 \sqrt{2} \, \text{N} \approx 141.4 \, \text{N} \).
